Key Arguments: The bill infringes upon the freedom of speech of Australian citizens.
It creates a discriminatory division between different sectors of society, allowing certain groups to spread information while silencing regular citizens.
The fines outlined in the bill could stifle speech more than existing digital services' restrictions.
The bill's scope includes not just false information but also information deemed 'misleading' or 'deceptive', which could inhibit open debate.
The delegation of legislative power to private entities raises constitutional concerns and compromises the separation of powers.
The bill violates the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
It could obstruct the democratic process by limiting access to information necessary for informed voting decisions.
Notable Quotes: This bill, in its current form, not only infringes upon the freedom of speech of Australian citizens but also creates a discriminatory division between different sectors of society.
The exorbitant fines outlined in the bill have the potential to stifle speech to a greater extent than any existing digital services' restrictions.
The delegation of legislative power to private entities under this bill raises constitutional concerns.
